title-group.article-title: Perirectal Oncologic Gateway to Retroperitoneal Endoscopic Single-Site Surgery (PROGRESSS)
title-group.subtitle: A Feasibility Study for a New NOTES Approach in a Swine Model

abstract.p: Introduction. A transanal, posterior, retrorectal approach has been demonstrated as a feasible natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery (NOTES) total mesorectal excision (TME) procedure. The aim was to assess the feasibility of a transrectal approach with a completely retroperitoneal mobilization of the left colon and mesenteric vessels in an acute porcine model. Materials and methods. Eight pigs were used. A purse-string suture was made 3 cm above the anal sphincter. Next, the retroperitoneal, perirectal space was entered with an endoscope through a single (or twin) anterior lateral, transrectal viscerotomy. A retroperitoneal tunnel was created using pneumodissection or endoscopically guided dissection to the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA). The IMA was skeletonized and lymph nodes retrieved using the IsisScope or other instruments. The IMA was divided with the Ligasure, clips, or ligature performed with the IsisScope. The rectum was dissected transanally in the “Holy” plane. After achieving mobilization using a completely retroperitoneal approach, the peritoneal attachments were then divided and the rectosigmoid specimen exteriorized through the anus. An explorative laparoscopy was then performed to evaluate the quality of the mobilization. Results. The procedure was successfully completed and the IMA correctly identified and ligated in all cases. In all but one case, no further mobilization was possible, even by a laparoscopic approach. Conclusions. Perirectal oncologic gateway to retroperitoneal endoscopic single-site surgery for left-sided colonic resections using both flexible and rigid surgical endoscopic platforms was feasible and reproducible in an acute porcine model. This technique might represent a step toward pure NOTES left-sided colorectal procedures.

kwd-group.kwd: perirectal oncologic gateway to retroperitoneal endoscopic single-site surgery (PROGRESSS)

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Colorectal natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery (NOTES) resections may represent a major advancement in minimally invasive surgery. The feasibility of a transrectal NOTES approach to colorectal surgery has been demonstrated in experimental settings.1-6 The combination of hybrid transrectal and the transabdominal approach takes advantages of both techniques in performing the critical steps, such as left colon mobilization, specimen extraction, and anastomosis construction. Additionally, in laparoscopic ultra-low rectal resections, the mobilization of the distal rectum, deep in the pelvis, is challenging because of the difficult exposure and might benefit from a combined transanal transabdominal approach, as demonstrated by Marks et al.7

Sylla et al,8 and more recently, Zorron et al,9 have presented some of the few available clinical experiences in oncologic patients with the transrectal NOTES total mesorectal excision (TME) using “hybrid” procedures involving some degree of laparoscopic assistance.

Sylla et al8 used a transanal endoscopic microsurgery (TEM) platform to enter the presacral plane, mobilize the mesorectum, and continue the posterior dissection cephalad until the visualization and the division of the peritoneal reflection with penetration in the peritoneal cavity. The peritoneal attachments of the rectosigmoid were divided using flexible bipolar and Thermaseal device.8

Zorron et al9 performed a TME through a perirectal pelvic retroperitoneal approach. The access to the perirectal extraperitoneal space was gained through a posterior transrectal viscerotomy using alternatively rigid and flexible instruments. In one case, a transanal single port device (Triport, Olympus, Tokyo, Japan) was used as surgical platform.

The main advantage of any retroperitoneal surgical approach is the prevention of unnecessary bowel manipulation, the reduction of surgical trauma, and also (especially for colorectal surgery) operation in the precise embryological fusion plane required for oncological resection, complete mesocolic preservation, and retroperitoneal structure identification (ureteric and gonadal vessel, lymph nodes).

Our concept aims to switch this approach to colonic resection and mobilization using an anterior lateral entry point to the perirectal retroperitoneum following embryologic and oncologic planes. This technique was named perirectal oncologic gateway for retroperitoneal endo-scopic single-site surgery (PROGRESSS).

In this concept, the access to the mesenteric vessels and lymph nodes is gained through a perirectal retroperitoneal approach, with rigid instruments (straight or roticulating), standard flexible endoscopes or a customary endoscopic surgical platform (IsisScope, Karl Storz, Tüttlingen, Germany) passed through a robust transanal endoscopic device (Transanal Endoscopic Operation TEO, Karl Storz, Tüttlingen, Germany) allowing for vascular control and lymph node retrieval without entering the abdominal cavity.

The aim of this preliminary study was to assess the feasibility and reproducibility of a transrectal, retroperitoneal approach to the left colon and mesenteric vessels in an acute porcine model. Additionally, we aimed to assess the interest of the combined use of a rigid transanal platform (TEO), which may accommodate a flexible endoscopic surgical platform or a conventional endoscope to improve the visualization of the transanal operative field once the dissection has been pursued beyond the level of the promontory. The acute model was selected for 2 reasons: First, the primary aim was to assess the ability to achieve a complete mobilization of the sigmoid colon by a purely retroperitoneal approach and not to assess the anastomosis in a survival model, and second, because of the terminal vascular anatomy of the distal colon and rectum in the pig, the rectosigmoid junction may suffer from ischemia in case of high vascular ligation.

sec.title: Animals
sec.p: Eight healthy pigs (6 males, 2 females, weighing from 30 to 70 kg) were used in this feasibility acute study.
All animals used in the experimental laboratory were managed according to French laws for animal use and care and to the directives of the European Community Council (number 86/609/EEC).

Pigs were fasted for 48 hours before surgery. Premedication by intramuscular injection of ketamine (7 mL) and azaperone (3 mL) (Stresnil, Janssen-Cilag, Belgium) was administered 1 hour before surgery. Induction was achieved by intravenous propofol (10 mL/30 kg) combined with pancuronium (2 mL). Anesthesia was maintained with 2% isoflurane. Intravenous antibiotic prophylaxis (Cephalexin 1 g) was administered. Bowel preparation by rectal enema was performed on table.

sec.title: Equipment
sec.p: The IsisScope flexible surgical platform is a new prototype, with an 18-mm diameter shaft, 55 cm in length, with two 4.3 mm and one 3.2 mm working channels, as well as 2 ergonomic handles to control operative instruments (Figure 1A).

caption.p: (A) The IsisScope is a novel surgical endoscopic platform,18 mm in diameter, 55 cm in length, has two 4.3 mm and one 3.2 mm working channels that accommodate endoscopic graspers and dissecting instruments. Two handles allow external manipulation of instruments in an ergonomic fashion. The tip of the IsisScope opens like a clam shell to provide surgical triangulation. (B) The Transanal Endoscopic Operation (TEO) standard faceplate (left) allows the introduction of laparoscopic instruments. The novel faceplate (right) presents a larger aperture that accommodates the IsisScope. (C) The setting of the perirectal oncologic gateway to retroperitoneal endoscopic single-site surgery (PROGRESSS) procedure: The IsisScope is introduced through the TEO

sec.p: The TEO is a platform conceived for TEM, with a dedicated instrumentation composed of a special endoscope (8 or 15 cm in length and 4 cm in diameter) equipped with high-definition video laparoscopic imaging system that allows precise manipulation of tissue, full-thickness resection and suturing of the rectal defect (Figure 1B).

sec.title: Step I: Closure of the rectal stump
sec.p: The pig lies in supine position under general anesthesia in steep Trendelenburg. A lubricated proctoscope is inserted per anum and a purse-string is performed 3 cm above the anal sphincter to close the rectal stump.

sec.title: Step II: Perirectal retroperitoneal approach
sec.p: The retroperitoneal perirectal space was entered with a single-channel endoscope (Karl Storz, Tüttlingen, Germany) through a single anterior lateral (2 o’clock, lithotomy position; Figures 2A and 3) transrectal viscerotomy. A retroperitoneal tunnel was fashioned using pneumodissection and endoscopically guided dissection with the assistance of 15 to 30 mm Hg carbon dioxide insufflations (Figure 2B). Dissection was carried out until the lower pole of the left kidney is identified. Subsequently, the inferior (caudal) mesenteric artery (IMA) and inferior mesenteric vein (IMV) were identified (Figure 4).

caption.p: Schematic representation of the procedure: (A) The retroperitoneal perirectal space was entered with a single-channel endoscope through a single anterior lateral (2 o’clock, lithotomy position) viscerotomy. (B) A retroperitoneal tunnel was fashioned using pneumodissection and endoscopically guided dissection with the assistance of 15 to 30 mm Hg carbon dioxide insufflations. (C) The inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) was skeletonized at its root and lymph nodes were retrieved using the IsisScope. (D) The Transanal Endoscopic Operation (TEO) device was inserted and a circumferential rectotomy was performed with the Ligasure device below the purse-string. (E) The rectum was dissected transanally toward the anterior and lateral presacral space without opening the pouch of Douglas. (F) Mobilization was continued until the root of the sigmoid, before the end of the spiral descending colon. (G) After complete mobilization, the specimen was exteriorized through the TEO device
Transanal endoscopic operation (TEO) view showing the rectal stump closed with a purse-string suture and the 2 o’clock viscerotomy to gain the perirectal retroperitoneal space
Endoscopic view showing the perirectal retroperitoneal tunnel and the inferior mesenteric artery and inferior mesenteric vein (arrow)

sec.p: To enter the retroperitoneum safely and create a large working space, 5 cm3 of saline were injected transanally through a Veress needle at 2 o’clock in lithotomy position in 4 cases. Additionally, a dilating balloon (SpaceMaker plus, Autosuture) was used in one case to create the working space. In 2 cases, a different approach was assessed (the lobster variant: Figure 5) entering the retroperitoneum with 2 endoscopes through twin anterior lateral (at 2 o’clock and 10 o’clock) ransrectal viscerotomies.

caption.p: The “lobster variant”: The retroperitoneum was entered with 2 endoscopes through twin anterior lateral (at 2 o’clock and 10 o’clock) transrectal viscerotomies

sec.title: Step III: Dissection of the IMA and IMV
sec.p: The IMA was skeletonized at its root and lymph nodes were retrieved using the IsisScope (3 cases; Figures 2C and 6) or rigid instruments (5 cases) passed through a flexible tube introduced through the viscerotomy parallel to the endoscope. The IMA and IMV were controlled with the Ligasure Advance (Covidien Valleylab, Norwalk, CT), clips, or a 2/0 Vicryl ligature performed with the IsisScope (Figure 7).

caption.p: Endoscopic view showing the inferior mesenteric artery (arrow) dissection using IsisScope micro-instruments
Endoscopic view showing the inferior mesenteric artery ligation with the IsisScope graspers

sec.title: Step IV: Rectosigmoid dissection
sec.p: After vascular ligation, rectal dissection was then accomplished introducing a novel TEO device with a bespoke aperture to introduce the IsisScope or a conventional endoscope, thereby allowing for the dissection to be carried on higher than the limited reach of the TEO endoscope instruments. After circumferentially scoring the rectum below the purse-string, a 360° rectotomy was performed using a 5-mm Ligasure Advance system (Figures 2D and 8). The rectum was dissected transanally toward the anterior and lateral presacral space without opening the pouch of Douglas (Figure 2E). Once the rectal stump was freed, the distal end was closed into an EndoCatch. To allow visualization at this point up to the promontory, an endoscope was introduced into the TEO device through a specifically modified faceplate (Figures 2F and 9). Mobilization was continued until the root of the sigmoid, before the end of the spiral descending colon. The distal end of the rectum was then pushed into the peritoneal cavity to expose the mesosigmoid root. At this point, the peritoneal cavity was accessed by opening the pouch of Douglas dividing the peritoneal attachments.

caption.p: Transanal Endoscopic Operation (TEO) view showing the circumferential opening of the rectum

Transanal Endoscopic Operation (TEO) view showing the interest of introducing an endoscope into the TEO device to achieve a close visualization when rectal dissection is pursued at the promontory and beyond. The surgeon’s view from the TEO perspective is limited by a blind angle and is not focused

sec.title: Step V: Transanal specimen extraction
sec.p: Once the mobilization was complete, the rectosigmoid was exteriorized transanally (Figure 10).

caption.p: Once dissected free, the rectosigmoid was pulled out through the Transanal Endoscopic Operation (TEO) device

sec.title: Step VI: Laparoscopic check
sec.p: At the end of the procedure, an exploratory laparoscopy was performed to assess correct identification of vascular structures, absence of any injury to the ureters, and adequacy of sigmoid mobilization.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The procedure was successfully completed and the IMA and IMV were correctly identified and controlled in all cases. The mean operative time was 158.33 minutes (SD = 45.78). In 3 cases, the peritoneum was punctured, but this did not affect the possibility to accomplish the retroperitoneal mobilization and required placement of a transabdominal Veress needle. One or two mesenteric lymph nodes were retrieved per pig. At laparoscopy, no further mobilization of the exteriorized specimen was possible in 7 out of 8 cases. In one case, the sigmoid colon was mobilized extending the dissection into the pelvis until reaching the plane created by the PROGRESSS approach. The saline injection before the creation of the working space was unnecessary to safely access the retroperitoneum.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The transanal NOTES approach to colorectal resections is a very appealing minimal access technique that avoids surgical trauma to the abdominal wall. The combination of transanal and transabdominal approach is helpful in performing difficult mobilization deep in the pelvis and laparoscopic total mesorectal excision (TME), especially for bulky tumors.10 The transanal rectal oncologic dissection in the “Holy” plane is challenging because of specific anatomical features (fusion of the presacral fascia and the fascia propria of the rectum) and several limitations in visualization and instrumentation.

To overcome these shortcomings, we have investigated the use of the TEO technology as a tool to facilitate the minimally invasive approach for left-sided NOTES colectomies in the experimental setting.4
This approach relies on the use of a 4-cm diameter rectoscope of various lengths with a dedicated optical system, which allows for the passage of various rigid, straight, and curved instruments.

These experiences showed that when the dissection is pursued at the level of the promontory or beyond, the TEO dedicated optic cannot achieve a good visualization. This problem is even more obvious after entering the abdominal cavity with a blind angle of view.

Based on this observation, in collaboration with Karl Storz, a modified version of the original TEO faceplate was developed at our institute that now permits the introduction of a latest generation of flexible endoscopic platforms (ie, the IsisScope) in the TEO device. This makes it possible to closely follow the dissection and/or to accomplish resections/sutures higher than the reach of TEO instruments.

In addition, transanal NOTES procedures share some of the challenges of the laparoendoscopic single-site surgery (LESS): (a) the in-line view provided by working instruments coming in the operative field from the same entry point of the optical system. (b) a progressively reduced surgical triangulation as the target of dissection progresses further, (c) the limited ability to retract and expose, and (d) the need for the surgeon to cross hands to reduce external conflicts between instruments. The IsisScope has been conceived to overcome these challenges. This multiple channel working device provides surgeons the perception of operating with “both hands” and recreates the basic principles of surgical manipulation and triangulation, in an endoluminal or transluminal environment, while simultaneously reducing external conflicts observed with other systems.
Using a transanal endoscopic platform or a flexible endoscope, Zorron et al9 performed a transanal posterior retrorectal approach for a NOTES TME procedure recently in 2 patients with rectal cancer.

Similar to this concept, our idea was a 2-staged procedure for an anterior lateral retroperitoneal transrectal oncologic access for lymph node retrieval and control of mesenteric vessels, and a posterior rectal mobilization from cranial to caudal in the “Holy” plane described by Heald et al11 but without entering the abdominal cavity.

The main difference is that the viscerotomy to access the retroperitoneal perirectal space is anterior lateral in the PROGRESSS technique. We believe that this entry point would give a better angle to find the “Holy” plane that lies above Waldeyer’s fascia formed by the fusion of the fascia propria and the presacral fascia.

Another specificity of the PROGRESSS approach is that, at least in the pig model, it allows for a higher mobilization of the mesocolon and vascular control of caudal mesenteric vessels and lymph node harvesting by a totally retroperitoneal approach, using pneumodissection and endoscopically guided dissection with carbon dioxide insufflation before creating any access to the peritoneal cavity or inserting any transanal device. In addition, the posterior aspect of the mid-rectum can also be mobilized by a twin PROGRESSS approach (The “lobster” variant) by entering the perirectal retroperitoneum through a twin 2 o’clock–10 o’clock viscerotomy.

The interest of the PROGRESSS approach goes beyond surgical resection. Recent studies have demonstrated the efficacy of localized resection in early rectal cancer through transanal endoscopic platforms with similar cure rates and a significantly lower morbidity.12 The problem with this approach is the impossibility of oncologic staging with lymph node harvesting.

Zerz et al13 in 2006 assessed the feasibility of a 2-staged procedure involving a dorsal posterior extraperitoneal pelviscopy in 11 consecutive patients with early-stage carcinoma of the lower third of the rectum. The pelvis was entered via the perineum and the operative space in the perirectal retroperitoneum was created with a dilating balloon, and a posterior endoscopic mesorectal resection was performed after transanal endoscopic excision of the tumor.13

Similarly, PROGRESSS access may be part of a TEM to achieve a minimally invasive oncologic staging with nodal status evaluation and, if need be, sentinel node detection in rectal or colon neoplasms as previously demonstrated by our group.14,15

One may argue about the challenge of the transrectal viscerotomy closure when PROGRESSS access is used solely for NOTES lymph node retrieval. In such cases, viscerotomy cannot be included in the specimen to be resected and its closure must be addressed.

Different solutions have been proposed to close the rectal viscerotomy such as placement of endo-loops and/or endo-clips,16 manual suture with TEO instruments, and linear stapler.17 We have recently proposed a novel stapled technique to close the viscerotomy4 by using an EEA hemorrhoid circular stapler (Covidien) in the setting of a transrectal NOTES sigmoidectomy, and we found it beneficial over a manual suture through a TEO device.18

Another point that could be raised is the risk of peritoneal contamination after creating the transrectal NOTES access during rectosigmoid mobilization. This issue has been assessed by our group in the experimental18 and in the clinical setting.19,20

Although we have previously shown that intraperitoneal bowel division (for either intraperitoneal anastomosis or natural orifice specimen extraction) results in a 100% rate of peritoneal contamination (compared with an 80% contamination rate for stapled bowel transection), there is no resultant increase in infective complications.

Another issue that needs to be carefully evaluated is the risk of local recurrence by a PROGRESSS approach. Using the transanal transabdominal technique, Marks et al7 have demonstrated no increase in recurrence rates in more than 100 patients. We hope that the approach itself would not increase the risk of recurrence by strictly complying with the principles of safe oncological surgery.

The last point that calls for attention is the theoretical risk of metastatic seeding while retrieving potentially invaded lymph nodes without adequate protection systems. Since the retroperitoneal space communicates with the peritoneal cavity, it provides one large continuous space in which infectious21 and neoplastic processes may spread.22 It would be mandatory to retrieve lymph nodes into specific devices (eg, wound protector or one-way extraction bag) to reduce the risk of diffuse carcinomatosis.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: PROGRESSS for left-sided colonic resection and mobilization using both flexible and rigid surgical endoscopic platforms was feasible and reproducible in an acute porcine model. This technique could well be a step toward pure NOTES rectal TME and/or sigmoidectomy. The possibility to retrieve mesenteric lymph nodes through a minimally invasive extraperitoneal access may provide an interesting staging procedure to complete transanal full-thickness resection of rectal tumors. The next logical step is to evaluate the technique in a human cadaver model.
